content.text: Measure and record the lengths of the three sides of the triangular sheet of card
length 1 =
length 2 =
Hang the card on the nail through hole **A**
Hang the plumbline from the nail so that it is close to the card but not touching it
When the card and plumbline are still, make a small mark at the edge of the card where the plumbline crosses the edge
Remove the card and draw a line from the mark to hole **A**
Repeat the steps in **(b)** using hole **B**
On your diagram on page 4,

show the positions of each of the holes \(\mathbf{A}\), \(\mathbf{B}\) and \(\mathbf{C}\) with a small, neat circle. Label each circle with the appropriate letter \((\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B}\) or \(\mathbf{C})\),
show the positions of each of the marks you made in (b)(iii) with a small neat cross (X),
draw the lines between the positions of the holes \(\mathbf{A}\), \(\mathbf{B}\) and \(\mathbf{C}\) and the corresponding marks, as on your sheet of card
Place your card in the space below and draw around its outline
If the experiment is completely accurate, the centre of mass of the card is at the position where the three lines meet
On your diagram judge the best position for the centre of mass
Draw a line from this position to the right-angled corner of the card and measure the distance a between the centre of mass and the right-angled corner of the card

In this experiment it is important that the card is able to swing freely. For this reason the plumbline should not touch the card, but be a small distance from the card. This could cause an inaccuracy in marking the card at the correct position (part (b)(iii))
Describe how you minimised the possible inaccuracy. You may draw a diagram
In this experiment you are to determine the position of the centre of mass of a triangle card
Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 1.1
You are provided with a small mass attached to a length of thread. This is referred to as the plumbline
Place the thermometer into the water as shown in Fig. 2.1
When the temperature shown on the thermometer stops rising, record the temperature \(\theta\) in Table 2.1 at time \(t = 0s\) and immediately start the stopclock
Record in the table the temperature of the water at 30 s intervals from \(t = 30 \text{s}\) until you have a total of seven values up to \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
Complete the column headings in the table
Calculate the temperature fall \(T_{1}\) during the first 30 s of cooling
Calculate the temperature fall \(T_{2}\) during the final 30 s of cooling
Plot the graph of temperature \((y\text{-axis})\) against time \((x\text{-axis})\)
State how the rate of cooling in the first 30 s differs from the rate of cooling in the final 30 s
Explain how the graph line shows this difference
In this experiment you will investigate the rate of cooling of water
Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 2.1. You are provided with a beaker of water
The circuit shown in Fig. 3.1 is set up for you
Switch on
Record in Table 3.1 the potential difference \(V\) across the lamps and the current \(I\) in lamp 1
Switch off
Rearrange the circuit so that the ammeter is connected in series with lamp 2
Switch on, and record in the table the potential difference \(V\) across the lamps and the current \(I\) in lamp 2
Switch off
Calculate the resistance \(R\) of each lamp, using the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\) and enter the results in the table
Add together the two values of \(R\) to calculate \(R_{\mathrm{S}}\), the sum of the resistances
RS =
Complete the column headings in the table
Record the readings on the voltmeter and the ammeter
voltmeter reading =
ammeter reading =
Use the voltmeter and ammeter readings to calculate \(R_{\mathrm{T}}\) the combined resistance of the two lamps in series
Rearrange the circuit so that the lamps and the ammeter are all in series. Do not change the position of the voltmeter
A student suggests that the values of \(R_{\mathrm{S}}\) and \(R_{\mathrm{T}}\) should be equal
State whether your results support this suggestion and justify your statement by reference to the calculated values
statement
justification

State, without reference to the values of resistance that you have calculated, one piece of evidence that you have observed during the experiment that shows that the temperature of the lamp filaments changes
In this experiment you will measure the currents in lamps in a circuit
Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 3.1
Draw a line \(10\mathrm{cm}\) long near the top of the ray trace sheet. Label the line \(\mathbf{MR}\). Draw a normal to this line at its centre. Label the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\)
Draw a line \(10\mathrm{cm}\) long that is parallel to line \(\mathbf{MR}\) and \(12\mathrm{cm}\) below it. Label this line \(\mathbf{CD}\)
Place the mirror, with its reflecting face vertical, on the line \(\mathbf{MR}\)

Place the card so that it stands vertically with end \(\mathbf{B}\) at \(\mathbf{C}\) and such that the card is at right angles to line \(\mathbf{CD}\) (see Fig. 4.1). Draw a line along the edge of the card and label the line \(\mathbf{AB}\)
Remove the card and the mirror. Draw a line from the edge \(\mathbf{A}\) of the card to the point \(\mathbf{N}\). Replace the card and the mirror
Place a pin \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) on line \(\mathbf{AN}\). Label the position of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\)
Measure and record in Table 4.1 the angle of incidence \(i\) between the line \(\mathbf{AN}\)
normal. Measure, and record in the table, the angle of reflection \(r\) between the normal and the line passing through \(\mathsf{P}_2\) and \(\mathsf{P}_3\)
(j) Repeat the steps (e)  (i) but using edge \(\mathbf{B}\) of the card instead of edge \(\mathbf{A}\)

(k) In spite of carrying out this experiment with care, it is possible that the values of the angle of reflection \(r\) will not be exactly the same as the values obtained from theory. Suggest two possible causes of this inaccuracy
**Tie in your ray trace sheet between pages 10 and 11.**

View the image of the edge \(\mathbf{A}\) of the card in the mirror from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 4.1. Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) some distance apart so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) , \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) and the reflections of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and the edge \(\mathbf{A}\) of the card, all appear exactly one behind the other. Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\)
In this experiment you will investigate the reflection of light by a plane mirror
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 4.1
